overview_summary: None of these five neighbors have a clearly documented public stance on development or clean energy, with all classified as "unknown" stance. Only one (a bank executive) appears to wield high influence locally, while the others are private residents with low public profiles or civic roles.

neighbors.name: Tommy A. Jerin and Amanda R. Jerin
neighbors.claims: Tommy A. Jerin has decades of experience in telecommunications and has served as a Telecom Operations Manager at DaVita Kidney Care since 1997 [The Org](https://theorg.com/org/davita/org-chart/tom-jerin). He also served as a 2nd Class Petty Officer in the U.S. Navy Reserve from 1992 to 2004 [The Org](https://theorg.com/org/davita/org-chart/tom-jerin). No public statements or civic positions for the Jerins were found in local records (stance on development is undocumented) [Berkeley County Assessor](https://www.theassessor.org/).

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage Mr. Jerin via a peer with a military or technical background, focusing on data-driven details. Emphasize that the project will be well-managed and won’t disrupt the quiet use of his property.

neighbors.name: Ann Marie Priddle
neighbors.claims: Ann M. Priddle is employed as a school bus operator for Berkeley County Schools [Berkeley County Schools](https://www.berkeleycountyschools.org/staff?filter_ids=315631&page_no=13). Aside from her occupation, there is no record of Priddle’s involvement in local boards or public commentary on development issues in Berkeley County [Berkeley County Assessor](https://www.theassessor.org/).

approach_recommendations.engage: Highlight traffic safety and roadway plans when communicating with Priddle. Given her role in student transportation, reassure her that construction traffic will be managed to ensure school bus routes remain safe and unobstructed.

neighbors.name: Christopher Graham
neighbors.claims: Christopher Graham is listed as a property owner in the Falling Waters area of Berkeley County, but no further public information about him (occupation, civic service, or statements on development) could be identified [Berkeley County Assessor](https://www.theassessor.org/). His profile appears limited to private landownership, with no news or official records indicating community leadership or stance on local projects [Berkeley County Assessor](https://www.theassessor.org/).

approach_recommendations.engage: Approach Graham with general courtesy and openness. Invite him to informational meetings and listening sessions to ensure his questions are answered, as he has no known prior engagement with community development issues.

neighbors.name: Joe Ernest Hronesz and Jessica Frances Hronesz
neighbors.claims: Joe E. Hronesz is a prominent local banker, serving as Senior Vice President and Chief Credit Officer of CNB Bank and recently named to become the bank’s next Chief Financial Officer in 2025 [CNB Bank Press Release](https://www.cnb.bank/Who-We-Are/News-and-Announcements/entryid/208/cnb-bank-announces-joe-hronesz-as-next-cfo). The bank’s announcement highlighted Hronesz’s 24+ years of experience in community banking and his leadership role in guiding the bank’s financial strategies [CNB Bank Press Release](https://www.cnb.bank/Who-We-Are/News-and-Announcements/entryid/208/cnb-bank-announces-joe-hronesz-as-next-cfo). There is no public record of the Hroneszes speaking for or against local development, but Joe’s high-profile business position suggests he is well-connected in the community [CNB Bank Press Release](https://www.cnb.bank/Who-We-Are/News-and-Announcements/entryid/208/cnb-bank-announces-joe-hronesz-as-next-cfo).

approach_recommendations.engage: Have the project’s economic or financial representative reach out to Hronesz. A data-rich discussion emphasizing local tax benefits, economic growth, and financial assurances will align with his business perspective and address any fiscal or investment concerns.

neighbors.name: Jonathan D. Smith and Tonya R. Smith
neighbors.claims: Jonathan D. Smith and Tonya R. Smith jointly own a parcel in this area, but research did not uncover any public details about their occupations, community involvement, or views on development [Berkeley County Assessor](https://www.theassessor.org/). They have maintained a low profile, with no mentions in local news or civic records related to land use debates or community leadership roles [Berkeley County Assessor](https://www.theassessor.org/).

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage the Smiths through one-on-one conversation to build trust. Since they are private residents, a friendly, informal approach—such as a neighborly visit or community open house—can encourage them to share any concerns or questions about the project.
